captions.text:
- Here's some things people
might not know about their cars.

Ralph Teetor, the inventor of
the cruise control, was blind.

The average American spends
about 38 hours a year
in traffic. That is a lot of time.

In most new models of cars,
you can see which side
of the car the gas tank is on.
It's the arrow right there.
If you have frosty windows in the morning,
try parking your car facing east.

Since the sun rises in
the east, the sun's warmth

should help defrost the
windows in the morning.
Science is crazy.

If your car is sweltering
on a hot summer day,
here's a good trick to cool it down.
Roll down your window all the way,
then walk to the other side of the car.
To create a circulating airflow,
open and close the door five to ten times.

This should lower the
temperature by ten degrees,

but be careful because
you might look stupid.

Use the A.C. when driving at
higher speeds to save gas.

Wind drag caused by open
windows is more gas consuming
than A.C. is when driving faster.

Try not to use the A.C.
when driving in traffic
because gas mileage can lower
when using A.C. at lower speeds.
Don't overfill your tank.
If using an automatic nozzle,
stop at the first click to save money.
You don't need anymore gas.
How to parallel park your car:

Start two feet forward from
the car with your bumpers

parallel and your wheels
turned all the way around.

Keep backing up with
the wheels fully turned
until you can see the back car's
license plate in the side mirror.

While stopped, turn the
wheels all the way around,
back it up, and park.
Also, this is a turn signal.
You might wanna use it when making a turn
or merging into another lane.
Thank you.

title: 10 Things People Don't Know About Their Cars

comments.author: FXloaphy

comments.text:
My Dad once explained why he never uses his turn signal: "It is not anyones 
business what I am doing when I drive!"
He honestly thought that by letting other drivers know his intentions, they 
would cut him off!
He also thought seat-belts were created by Ralph Nader as a way to force 
people to stay in their cars during a crash.  Yeah, he was part of the 
'thrown free' generation.
Somehow, in a car crash, being thrown free of the collision is supposed to 
save you from serious injury.
Over on LiveLeak, it is easy to see what happens when folks get 'saved' by 
flying through the air after a wreck.﻿

comments.author: angedgangsta

comments.text:
So, that's what a dumb list looks like!

Here's a real list:
* Gas goes "bad" after a while.  It's good to run your car through most of 
your gas once every couple of months.  Do this by knowing how much fuel 
your tank holds (which most people do not know) and occasionally make sure 
that when you refill there is 1/4 gallon or less fuel in the car.  There's 
no need to run yourself totally out of gas to make this happen.  As you get 
more familiar with your car you'll get better and better about gauging when 
this happens.

* Higher octane than recommended by the car manual doesn't do anything for 
your car or increase fuel economy.  Your car requires a certain minimal 
amount of octane to prevent engine knocking (which happens when fuel 
ignites at unintended times during the 4 stroke phases).  If you meet that 
minimum octane you're fine.

* Accelerating rapidly is one of the worst things you can do for your fuel 
economy.  Make a point of accelerating a little more slowly, and if you 
have a manual transmission, shift gears earlier in the rev range.  Do this 
and you'll notice a significant improvement in fuel economy with any kind 
of stop and go driving.

* Maintaining a high rate of speed is another of the worst things you can 
do for your fuel economy.  The aerodynamics of your car make it function 
like a plow moving aside air.  The faster the car is moving the more fuel 
it will require to push all of that air out of the way.  As an example 
driving a 2014 Toyota Camry at 75 is like paying 15% more for each gallon 
of gas instead of driving that same car at 65.  A more aerodynamic car (in 
car stats it's referred to as Cd) will burn less extra fuel for traveling 
at similar speeds.

* Leaving a truck bed door down makes a truck less aerodynamic.  Placing a 
cover over the bed is one of the best ways to improve a truck's 
aerodynamics.

* Oversteer is when you try to turn a car and the rear of the car breaks 
loose and slides out in the turn.  In effect the car will turn/rotate more 
than intended.  

* Understeer is when you try to turn a car and the front fails to turn as 
much as you intended.  In effect the car will turn/rotate less than you 
intended.

* The majority of a car's ability to brake comes from the front tires.  If 
your front tires lock up you're losing traction and your ability to brake 
decreases.  This will also mean that under heavy braking you will have less 
ability to turn because you're diverting traction to slowing the car and 
have less traction to divert to turning the car.  This means if you want to 
avoid an accident locking your brakes and turning your wheel will leave you 
going in a straight line and braking poorly.

* Unless you have a car that is track ready from the manufacturer your 
spoiler is just for looks.  Of the spoilers that are functional, most 
spoilers don't provide and significant down force until at high speed (a 
2004 WRX STi spoiler provides about 60 pounds of downforce at about 100mph 
- so most major car audio systems will technically provide more downforce 
than even most functional spoilers).  Some race cars produce enough 
downforce to effectively drive upside down (because the air moving over the 
car exerts more force than the gravitational pull of the planet). 

* Not placing your seat belt in your lap properly in a major cause of 
prolapsed rectums in car accidents.  Yeah, have fun looking that up.﻿

comments.author: Ethan Jorge

comments.text:
LOL at window-down-door-flap technique. The best way to cool the car is to 
just open all windows to your car. Almost every car has this option on the 
key fob so you can do it while walking to your car. Even in very low wind 
the car is cooled faster than flapping the door. If there is no wind, let 
it 30 sec with windows open, get in and just drive with them open for 1-2 
minutes, the best part is that you can start the A/C during this time, and 
by the time you close the windows the A/C is already cooling.

Remember: A/C System on every car works way better when the car is moving 
because the radiator is cooled better by natural airflow than by the fans 
it is supplied with.﻿

When going at speeds above 80 km/h (~45mp/h), the wind resistance creates 
so much drag that the shape of your car makes a big difference.
Sometimes when you're driving and a strong wind blows you from the side you 
can feel how your car leans little bit to the direction of the wind.
The same thing is happening in front of your car continuously, except that 
its much stronger.
